newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil landless face off against land barons.
newsitem.headline: Brazil landless face off against land barons.

text.p: Thousands of landless Brazilian peasants faced off against landowners in the state of Sao Paulo on Saturday and the situation was "extremely tense," officials for both sides said.

Leaders of the militant Landless Movement (MST) said 3,000 peasants held a mass gathering in the region of Pontal do Paranapanema, where MST squatters occupying farmland have clashed frequently with estate owners in recent months.
The landowners reacted by holding their own meeting on Saturday morning in protest at the invasions.
"The situation is extremely tense but so far there have been no incidents," said a spokesman for Sao Paulo state governor Mario Covas. "The state government is watching the situation carefully."
More than 300 military police officers from the region were drafted in to ensure there was no bloodshed, he added.

"We are going to show our strength to the land barons," Jose Rainha Junior, MST leader in Pontal do Paranapanema, told the Folha de Sao Paulo newspaper. "They have their hired guns and think they can do whatever they want. We want to show them we just want some land to plant."
Brazil has one of the world's worst distributions of wealth, a fact reflected in land ownership. The Catholic Church says 80 percent of arable land is in the hands of 10 percent of landowners.

A recent acceleration in MST land invasions has led to angry exchanges with the government and also increased tension in the countryside, where so-called "Colonels" who rule like feudal barons frequently react by sending in their hired guns.
Thirty-six people have died so far this year in such conflicts, including 19 landless peasants massacred by police in April in the northern state of Para.
